JUNIOR-SENIOR
DEBATE POSTPONED
At the request of the Seniors, who have been unable to
devote much time to the preparation of their argument, the
Annual Junior-Senior debate,
which was to have taken place
Thursday, has been postponed
a week and will be given at
the Assembly on March 1.
The Junior team consists of
Ness, chairman; Driver and
Brown. The members of the
Senior group are Gardner,
chairman; Blandi and M. S.
Hecht.

Hopkins Quint Far From Being
Out of Race, Says Darley
GEORGETOWN TO FOLLOW
Washington Quint has Dropped
Only One Game this Year
"We are not out of the race for
the state title by a jug full.. Who
wrote all this about our 'title hopes
being blasted'?" Thus Coach George
Darley vigorously denied that his
team was out of the running in the
race for state court honors, and
pointed out that every state team
had lost at least one game to a Maryland opponent. "The team's spirit
has not lagged for a moment," he
added, "and is the finest I have ever
seen on any team."

TOMORROW'S GAME
AT 104th ARMORY
As a result of the fire at Carlin's, Friday, Manager Baurenschmidt of the basket-ball
team is now faced with the
problem of finding a court for
the remaining home games.
Tomorrow's baske tball game with Georgetown
will be played at the One Hundred and Fourth Armory. It
will be preceded by a Catholic
League championship contest.
It is probable that the remaining three games scheduled
for home will be played at
Loyola College's gymnasium
at Evergreen.

COLLEGE STUDENTS AND RELIGION
The high spot of the collegiate week-end was the meeting of
presidents, deans, and headmasters of Eastern universities, colleges, and preparatory schools held at Princeton. Here the godless undergraduate was discussed by his teachers from the poin of
view of the change in his religious attitude.
As we might have suspected, the most intelligent opinion was
expressed by President Enoch B. Garey of St. Johns, who said, "I
question whether a religion born 2,000 years ago in Asia is necessarily the last word for today." Dr. Garey, moreover, was, according to dispatches from the daily press, more inclined than any of
his colleagues to credit the undergraduate with having a more or
less satisfactory basis for his apparent scepticism. Dean Sperry
of the Harvard Divinity School believes that the reason why
religion apparently has so little influence on college students is that
students are an unthinking, gullible lot who have merely shifted
their credulity from the Sunday-school teacher to the biology
professor. Between these two extremes were other views, but
the leaning was toward the belief that undergraduates are preeminently irreligious.
The fact of the matter is, however, that most college students
are really agnostic; they don't know. Those who give any thought
at all to religion realize that the sheer impotency of man is evidence of the existence of some greater power, to which he applies
the name God. But few students conceive of any definite tangible'
relationship between God and themselves. Moreover, they are
inclined to be intellectually lazy; they accept the surface values
of life without caring about its other possibilities. In addition,
the average student, being young and untouched by great emotional
upheavals, does not find the necessity for faith. Is it any wonder,
then, that when the forms of religion do not appeal to the student,
when there seems to be so many descrepancies between what
religion teaches him and what he finds in the world around him,
and when his life apparently is sufficiently full without religion,
that religion exerts little or no influence upon him?
We full well realize that we utter the grossest kind of platitude
when we say that college students do not think. This fact does
not indicate, however, that they are necessarily gullible. The
reason for the general irreligious attitude of undergraduates, and
for that of much of the world as a whole, for that matter, will be
more likely, ultimately, to be found in Dr. Garey's statement than
in Dean Sperry's.

Home Concert Seats
Selling Rapidly
Full House Expected to Greet Glee
Club at Maryland Casualty
Clubhouse, Friday

All seats at the Maryland Casualty Clubhouse will probably be filled
Friday night for the Johns Hopkins Musical Club concert, according to Ostnar P. Steinwald, student
director of the club.
A few good seats have not as yet
been sold, however, and students desiring tickets can procure them from
Steinwald or Kolb at the Barn every
day at noon, or at Albaugh's Ticket
Office, 12 E. Lexington street.
The encouraging ticket sale has
been largely due to the excellent
publicity stunts of the club. A radio concert was given last night over
station W. B. A. L., and 3000 post
cards were sent out to alumni of the
University.
The combined Musical Clubs
will journey to Hagerstown on the
second of March to give a concert
and dance at the State Armory
under the auspices of the Women's
Club of Hagerstown. The men will
stay in Hagerstown overnight and
then go to Chambersburg on the
next day, where they will give a
concert and dance at Wilson College under the auspices of the Sophomore Class. The members of the
club will return to Baltimore that
same night.
The trip will be made in two large
'buses and about sixty men will make
the journey.

COLLEGE STUDENTS AND RELIGION
The high spot of the collegiate week-end was the meeting of
presidents, deans, and headmasters of Eastern universities, colleges, and preparatory schools held at Princeton. Here the godless undergraduate was discussed by his teachers from the poin of
view of the change in his religious attitude.
As we might have suspected, the most intelligent opinion was
expressed by President Enoch B. Garey of St. Johns, who said, "I
question whether a religion born 2,000 years ago in Asia is necessarily the last word for today." Dr. Garey, moreover, was, according to dispatches from the daily press, more inclined than any of
his colleagues to credit the undergraduate with having a more or
less satisfactory basis for his apparent scepticism. Dean Sperry
of the Harvard Divinity School believes that the reason why
religion apparently has so little influence on college students is that
students are an unthinking, gullible lot who have merely shifted
their credulity from the Sunday-school teacher to the biology
professor. Between these two extremes were other views, but
the leaning was toward the belief that undergraduates are preeminently irreligious.
The fact of the matter is, however, that most college students
are really agnostic; they don't know. Those who give any thought
at all to religion realize that the sheer impotency of man is evidence of the existence of some greater power, to which he applies
the name God. But few students conceive of any definite tangible'
relationship between God and themselves. Moreover, they are
inclined to be intellectually lazy; they accept the surface values
of life without caring about its other possibilities. In addition,
the average student, being young and untouched by great emotional
upheavals, does not find the necessity for faith. Is it any wonder,
then, that when the forms of religion do not appeal to the student,
when there seems to be so many descrepancies between what
religion teaches him and what he finds in the world around him,
and when his life apparently is sufficiently full without religion,
that religion exerts little or no influence upon him?
We full well realize that we utter the grossest kind of platitude
when we say that college students do not think. This fact does
not indicate, however, that they are necessarily gullible. The
reason for the general irreligious attitude of undergraduates, and
for that of much of the world as a whole, for that matter, will be
more likely, ultimately, to be found in Dr. Garey's statement than
in Dean Sperry's.

All seats at the Maryland Casualty Clubhouse will probably be filled

Office, 12 E. Lexington street.

been largely due to the excellent
publicity stunts of the club. A radio concert was given last night over
station W. B. A. L., and 3000 post
cards were sent out to alumni of the
University.
The combined Musical Clubs
will journey to Hagerstown on the
second of March to give a concert
and dance at the State Armory
under the auspices of the Women's
Club of Hagerstown. The men will
stay in Hagerstown overnight and
then go to Chambersburg on the
next day, where they will give a
concert and dance at Wilson College under the auspices of the Sophomore Class. The members of the
club will return to Baltimore that
same night.

'buses and about sixty men will make
the journey.
